PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have written it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Mrs. R. Gasperina V.S.S. I.H.S.
2. Your address: 517 8th Ave., Regina, B.C.
3. Date: April 3.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   (Perkney, Saskatchewan, U.K.)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Nicholas Gasperina, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   Came to Perkney October 13, 1911
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   (Moved from Perkney January 1905 to Canada (Abbots) in 1911)
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", etc.)
   6 years old, 1911
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Reason was my father's health (climate)
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Through friends who had come to Canada in order to come back to Saskatchewan and who came from the same place as we did which was Perkney, Minnesota. So they came in the years 1906 to 1911. They said that they came to Canada in the same way. Before this were at least 8 to 10 different families that came. Before we did, most of them were pioneers. We would all get together for a evening dance which always included playing cards, laughing, and music. The fellowship family lasted all through the Depression. Because my father was a worker and a hard worker, he was able to help us. We also won a few prizes in the fair and the church.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were happy because they were neighbors in the United States of ours, and good friends.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad & P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

When we arrived at Prince Albert, we traveled on a wagon train. When we left, we traveled on a train. We came along the prairie so our place they shipped to let us all fit our wagons hitched out and it was my aunt's birthday. On April 13, 1911, she was held up by the wagon and we stole into the garden which was very nice. She got into the one car but for every one of us. Then got into the one car and finished our journey which was 36 miles to go out to our brothers' shack.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At my brother's shack which was 18 miles N.E. from Vanguard.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In the municipality of La Tonia 18 miles N.E. from Vanguard.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

How after you came? At first I was too young to work, then worked at housework for a number of years until my husband was killed in the railroad switchyard for three years. Then I worked in the telephone at the B.C. in the hospital in the railway station, my eldest brother had a lumber plant in operation killed in a train accident and left the valley.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were very happy because they were neighbors in the United States.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad L.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey? What do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

When we arrived at the Saskatchewan River, we traveled on a wagon train. When we left, we traveled on a wagon train. We came along the river, so our plan was to go to the railroad station. All of our things were loaded onto the train, and we were very excited.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At my brother's house for about two weeks. Then we moved into our new home.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In the municipality of La Toque, 18 miles N.E. from Vanguard.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How did you work?
I stayed at my sister and her husband (who is now deceased) but before he died; they moved, had sold on 40 ave & Cloverdale and moved to 176 street where the Victor Brisco was living when he died. We lived at 176 street & Cloverdale from 1960 to 1973 then my sister sold her home and we moved into Cloverdale into the Benberg apartments 17788 - 51 ave Suite 210 where we still live and will stay until the good Lord calls me.

   I don't recall.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   No car before 1914.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   We traded mostly in Weyburn. It was 15 miles later on there was a town named Willingwood and that was 9 miles and another town named Edenham that we didn't go very often.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We traded in Weyburn because we could get almost everything we needed although we took our own wheat to Herbert which was thirty miles to the flour mill and had it ground then took some extra flour home.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   When ever we needed anything.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   I can't recall when but I know we went for dances included.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   My dad came for his health so I can't say that we had intentions of moving anywhere else or whether he would have stayed. He (my dad) died at the age of 68.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
   No, no one moved out of the district. The fact is people were just moving into the district.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
   Yes, they moved away and did not return.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
   My dad was on the school board and the school was named after my dad.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
   The lake that bordered my Dad's farm (Henry Davis was named Harpers Lake). The school I attended (and sisters and brothers) was named after my Dad (Harpers School), and I can only recall one town that the name was changed, from Bellewood changed to Dendron and my Dad build the first big barn for miles around and every summer Dad would let our love dances in there and we had a collie dog that kept people from drinking or effeminate. He simple would not let anyone act up. He sure was a smart dog, all Dad had to say, "I told ya watch them, and he did."
